mscVrPpTbclRowStatusTable.name: mscVrPpTbclRowStatusTable
mscVrPpTbclRowStatusTable.description: This entry controls the addition and deletion of mscVrPpTbcl components.

mscVrPpTbclRowStatusEntry.name: mscVrPpTbclRowStatusEntry
mscVrPpTbclRowStatusEntry.description: A single entry in the table represents a single mscVrPpTbcl component.

mscVrPpTbclRowStatus.name: mscVrPpTbclRowStatus
mscVrPpTbclRowStatus.description: This variable is used as the basis for SNMP naming of mscVrPpTbcl components. These components can be added and deleted.

mscVrPpTbclComponentName.name: mscVrPpTbclComponentName
mscVrPpTbclComponentName.description: This variable provides the component's string name for use with the ASCII Console Interface

mscVrPpTbclStorageType.name: mscVrPpTbclStorageType
mscVrPpTbclStorageType.description: This variable represents the storage type value for the mscVrPpTbcl tables.

mscVrPpTbclIndex.name: mscVrPpTbclIndex
mscVrPpTbclIndex.description: This variable represents the index for the mscVrPpTbcl tables.

mscVrPpTbclProvTable.name: mscVrPpTbclProvTable
mscVrPpTbclProvTable.description: This group houses all the provisionable attributes that belong to the this group. This group of attributes is applicable to all types of bridge ports and represent the common factor between them. These attributes influence the working of a bridge port.

mscVrPpTbclTranslateIpx.name: mscVrPpTbclTranslateIpx
mscVrPpTbclTranslateIpx.description: This attribute specifies the type of translation to be performed on frames carrying IPX packets. Ethernet frames carrying IPX payload could be translated to IEEE 802.3 frames (with the same IPX payload) or vice- versa. The main reason to do so is to allow the bridge unit to consistently forward one type of frames carrying IPX packets. Translations can be turned off altogether in which case the IPX frames will pass through the bridge unit unchanged.

mscVrPpTbclFragmentIp.name: mscVrPpTbclFragmentIp
mscVrPpTbclFragmentIp.description: This attribute specifies if or not outbound frames carrying IP datagrams should be fragmented to conform to message transfer unit (mtu) sizes dictated by the media.

mscVrPpTbclServiceClass.name: mscVrPpTbclServiceClass
mscVrPpTbclServiceClass.description: This attribute specifies if the frames should be ordered or not before they are transmitted through a bridge port. If this attribute has a value of ordered the received frames are ordered as in the original message, before they are transmitted out through a bridge port. If it has a value of notOrdered, received then frames pass through the bridge unit in the order they are received. This feature can be used over multiple telecommunication links to increase data flow. Please note that this attribute only affects link protocols and is ineffective with lan media.

mscVrPpTbclConvertArpMacAddress.name: mscVrPpTbclConvertArpMacAddress
mscVrPpTbclConvertArpMacAddress.description: This attribute is indicative of the state of the MAC address format conversion process for ARP/RARP frames. The MAC addresses may be translated if need be from a canonical format to a non-canonical format, based on the needs of the associated media. If this attribute is set to a value of on then all Mac addresses will converted if need be to suit the format of mac address, the outgoing media will support. If this attribute is set to a value of off no such conversion takes place.

mscVrPpTbclPortNum.name: mscVrPpTbclPortNum
mscVrPpTbclPortNum.description: This attribute is indicative of the unique number assigned to the bridge port. It is used for SNMP management of this bridge port and in spanning tree as an identifier this bridge port. Notes regarding portNum: Escape routines exist for initializing, copying, and deleting port numbers. This is necessary because SNMP requires a unique port instance identifier. The initPortNum escape routine sets the port number to a value in the range 1-255 for this purpose. The setCopiedPortNum escape routine exists to maintain the uniqueness of the port number in cases when one port is copied to another. When a bridge port is deleted, the releasePortNum escape routine places the port number being released into a pending deletion state. This is because the port number cannot be re-allocated until the port is truely deleted in the current view. This is necessary since there is no guarantee of order when processing changes to multiple protocol ports so without the pending deletion state, the same port number could be temporarily assigned to two ports for a short period of time. The portNum is set as component critical since bridging also uses the port number as a key for indexing into its data structures. If a port is deleted then re-added under the same protocol port, CAS treats the change as a SET to the portNum attribute.

mscVrPpTbclTbProvTable.name: mscVrPpTbclTbProvTable
mscVrPpTbclTbProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes that belong to the Tb group. The Tb group is only applicable bridge port types that operate in the TB mode. These attributes in part influence the working of a bridge port operating in the TB mode.

mscVrPpTbclSecureOption.name: mscVrPpTbclSecureOption
mscVrPpTbclSecureOption.description: This attribute specifies whether the port secure feature is enabled. The secure feature, if enabled causes the following things to happen: a) disallows dynamic learning, b) disallows frames to be forwarded that do not satisfy the following condition: the mac address of the source should be found in the forwarding table and the destination mac address of the frame should also be found in the forwarding table. In addition to this, the port the frame was received on should figure as the in port, given the destination mac address found in the frame. c) disallows frames to be forwarded if the allowed to go port map for the destination mac address is empty. This feature in effect allows the user to choose the hosts that can generate traffic and the hosts that can receive traffic through this bridge unit.

mscVrPpTbclStpProvTable.name: mscVrPpTbclStpProvTable
mscVrPpTbclStpProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes that belong to the Stp group. The Stp group is applicable to all the bridge ports that participate in the spanning tree protocol. These attributes influence the participation of the bridge port in the spanning tree protocol.

mscVrPpTbclAdminStatus.name: mscVrPpTbclAdminStatus
mscVrPpTbclAdminStatus.description: This attribute defines the current administrative state for this component. enabled indicates that the component is available for operation. disabled indicates the component is unavailable for operation.

mscVrPpTbclPortStateStpControl.name: mscVrPpTbclPortStateStpControl
mscVrPpTbclPortStateStpControl.description: This attribute specifies whether or not spanning tree protocol state for this bridge port is controlled by the spanning tree protocol. In essence it indicates the participation of this bridge port in the spanning tree protocol, by accepting and acting on received bridge protocol data units and by sending out the same. on signifies that this bridge port's spanning tree port state is controlled by the spanning tree protocol. A value of off signifies that the spanning tree port state of this bridge port is unaffected by the spanning tree protocol. This in effect puts the bridge port out of reach of the spanning tree protocol and in the forwarding state. Care should be taken while assigning a value of off to this attribute, as this might cause network loops. Please do not set this attribute to off unless you are absolutely sure about the effect of such an action on your network topology.

mscVrPpTbclStpTypeProv.name: mscVrPpTbclStpTypeProv
mscVrPpTbclStpTypeProv.description: This attribute specifies the type of spanning tree protocol the port is participating in. A bridge port could participate in either the ieee8021 spanning tree protocol or the dec spanning tree protocol. If the value of the attribute protocolSpec in the SpanningTreeProtocol component, provisioned under the TransparentBridge component is in conflict with the value of this attribute, the value of the protocolSpec attribute will prevail. Prevailing stp type is reflected in the value of the attribute stpTypeOper.

mscVrPpTbclPortPriority.name: mscVrPpTbclPortPriority
mscVrPpTbclPortPriority.description: This attribute specifies the value for port priority, which is contained in the first octet of the port identifier. Valid values are as follows: 1) 0..255 for stp type DEC and 2) 0..65535 for stp type IEEE.

mscVrPpTbclPathCost.name: mscVrPpTbclPathCost
mscVrPpTbclPathCost.description: This attribute specifies the contribution of this port, to all the paths to the root bridge that include this port. Please note that the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is applied only when the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is set to on and is ignored if otherwise.

mscVrPpTbclPathCostMethod.name: mscVrPpTbclPathCostMethod
mscVrPpTbclPathCostMethod.description: This attribute specifies the method used by the bridging logic, to calculate the path cost to the bridge considered to be the root bridge in the spanning tree topology. This attribute should be set to off before attempting to provision a value for pathCostProv.

mscVrPpTbclDIProvTable.name: mscVrPpTbclDIProvTable
mscVrPpTbclDIProvTable.description: This group houses all the provisionable, domain specific attributes for a non-encapsulating bridge port.

mscVrPpTbclDomainNum.name: mscVrPpTbclDomainNum
mscVrPpTbclDomainNum.description: This attribute specifies the domain number associated with this bridge port. Domain numbers are used for confining frames to a domain. Domain based filtering provides a complete segregation of traffic based on domain number associated with frames. There can exist only sixteen domains when a spanning tree is desired specific to each domain. When there is only a single spanning tree spanning all the domains the maximum number of domains possible are 4294967293. This attribute is of no relevance when associated with backbone bridge port. Its value is ignored in such a situation.

mscVrPpTbclPreserveDomain.name: mscVrPpTbclPreserveDomain
mscVrPpTbclPreserveDomain.description: This attribute specifies if the domain information should be preserved or embedded in the frame header. This attribute applies only to backbone ports and does not affect the access bridge ports. By setting this attribute to a value of on, domain information could be preserved in frames being tunnelled across the a backbone, so that this information can be deciphered at the other end of the backbone tunnel. This preserves the integrity of the domains thus preventing domain breaches while tunnelling frames across backbone network. If the value of this attribute is set to off then domain information is not preserved in the header of the frames tunnelling through the backbone. This eliminates the overhead incurred to preserve domain information across the backbone while tunnelling frames across it. Preserve domain is relevant when used in conjunction with the following media: FDDI, ATM MPE, Frame Relay and PPP. It is ignored when used with other types of media.

mscVrPpTbclStateTable.name: mscVrPpTbclStateTable
mscVrPpTbclStateTable.description: This group contains the three OSI State attributes. The descriptions generically indicate what each state attribute implies about the component. Note that not all the values and state combinations described here are supported by every component which uses this group. For component-specific information and the valid state combinations, refer to NTP 241-7001-150, Passport Operations and Maintenance Guide.

mscVrPpTbclAdminState.name: mscVrPpTbclAdminState
mscVrPpTbclAdminState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Administrative State of the component. The value locked indicates that the component is administratively prohibited from providing services for its users. A Lock or Lock - force command has been previously issued for this component. When the value is locked, the value of usageState must be idle. The value shuttingDown indicates that the component is administratively permitted to provide service to its existing users only. A Lock command was issued against the component and it is in the process of shutting down. The value unlocked indicates that the component is administratively permitted to provide services for its users. To enter this state, issue an Unlock command to this component.

mscVrPpTbclOperationalState.name: mscVrPpTbclOperationalState
mscVrPpTbclOperationalState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Operational State of the component. The value enabled indicates that the component is available for operation. Note that if adminState is locked, it would still not be providing service. The value disabled indicates that the component is not available for operation. For example, something is wrong with the component itself, or with another component on which this one depends. If the value is disabled, the usageState must be idle.

mscVrPpTbclUsageState.name: mscVrPpTbclUsageState
mscVrPpTbclUsageState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Usage State of the component. The value idle indicates that the component is not currently in use. The value active indicates that the component is in use and has spare capacity to provide for additional users. The value busy indicates that the component is in use and has no spare operating capacity for additional users at this time.

mscVrPpTbclOperStatusTable.name: mscVrPpTbclOperStatusTable
mscVrPpTbclOperStatusTable.description: This group includes the Operational Status attribute. This attribute defines the current operational state of this component.

mscVrPpTbclSnmpOperStatus.name: mscVrPpTbclSnmpOperStatus
mscVrPpTbclSnmpOperStatus.description: The current state of the interface. The up state indicates the interface is operational and capable of forwarding packets. The down state indicates the interface is not operational, thus unable to forward packets. testing state indicates that no operational packets can be passed.

mscVrPpTbclOperTable.name: mscVrPpTbclOperTable
mscVrPpTbclOperTable.description: This group houses all the operational attributes belonging to the base group. The base group of attributes is applicable to all types of bridge ports and represent the common factor between them. These attributes in part, reflect the state of a bridge port.

mscVrPpTbclPortName.name: mscVrPpTbclPortName
mscVrPpTbclPortName.description: The attribute portName is a string of the form 'BridgePortName-i', where BridgePortName is the abbreviation of the corresponding bridge port and i is the instance identifier of the ProtocolPort, the bridge port is provisioned under. For example a TransparentBridgePort provisioned under ProtocolPort/myport would have a name TBP-myport.

mscVrPpTbclUpTime.name: mscVrPpTbclUpTime
mscVrPpTbclUpTime.description: This attribute specifies the accumulated up time of this bridge port since the last reset occurred.

mscVrPpTbclDownTime.name: mscVrPpTbclDownTime
mscVrPpTbclDownTime.description: This attribute specifies the accumulated down time of this bridge port since the last reset occurred.

mscVrPpTbclBridgingMode.name: mscVrPpTbclBridgingMode
mscVrPpTbclBridgingMode.description: This attribute specifies the mode of bridging this port can support. It in turn implies the format of frames, this bridge port can process and forward.

mscVrPpTbclBridgePortConfig.name: mscVrPpTbclBridgePortConfig
mscVrPpTbclBridgePortConfig.description: This attribute specifies the bridge port's configuration. It indicates if the bridge port is operating as an access port or as a backbone port. An access bridge port does not encapsulate a MAC frame and does not preserve domain information in the encapsulation, whereas a backbone bridge port encapsulates the MAC frame and optionally preserves domain information in the encapsulated frame.A backbone bridge port is typically used to transport frames across a high bandwidth backbone network to another bridge unit for further processing/forwarding of the frame.

mscVrPpTbclBridgePortType.name: mscVrPpTbclBridgePortType
mscVrPpTbclBridgePortType.description: This attribute specifies the type of bridge port that was provisioned. It takes into consideration the bridgingMode, bridgePortConfig and the media the bridge port is linked to before branding a bridge port.

mscVrPpTbclIfIndex.name: mscVrPpTbclIfIndex
mscVrPpTbclIfIndex.description: This attribute specifies the index into the Interface Table where in information about the media interface corresponding to the bridge port is maintained.

mscVrPpTbclDelayExceededDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbclDelayExceededDiscards
mscVrPpTbclDelayExceededDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because the time taken to process these frames exceeded the transit delay allowed for this bridge unit. This attribute is not supported by bridging and will always have a value of 0.

mscVrPpTbclMtuExceededDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbclMtuExceededDiscards
mscVrPpTbclMtuExceededDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded because the size of the out bound frame exceeded the message transfer unit (mtu) allowed for the bridge port. Note that this counter only refers to the outbound frames for this bridge port. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. This counter is influenced by the attribute fragmentIp. This counter is incremented when the a frame larger than the mtu allowed is encountered and cannot be fragmented. If this counter is increasing steadily, it might be useful to set the value of the attribute fragmentIp to a value of on.

mscVrPpTbclTbOperTable.name: mscVrPpTbclTbOperTable
mscVrPpTbclTbOperTable.description: This group houses all the port specific operational attributes that belong to the Tb group. This group also houses all the port specific statistical attributes that belong to the Tb group. The Tb group is only applicable bridge port types that operate in the TB mode. These attributes reflect the state of a bridge port operating in the TB mode

mscVrPpTbclMaxInfo.name: mscVrPpTbclMaxInfo
mscVrPpTbclMaxInfo.description: This attribute specifies the maximum size of the information field in a TB frame. This excludes the header field.

mscVrPpTbclBadVerifyDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbclBadVerifyDiscards
mscVrPpTbclBadVerifyDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that were discarded because: a) the value of the secureOption attribute was set to on and b) it is not allowed to receive frames originating from the mac address found in the source address field of the frame (source mac address look up in the forwarding table failed.) on this bridge port. c) for the destination mac address found in the frame, the port the frame was received on does not appear as in port in the corresponding static table entry. Permission to receive frames from a mac address is granted via the static table entries. This attribute, badVerifyDiscards, is directly influenced by: 1. secureOption and 2. the static table entries. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpTbclUnicastNoMatches.name: mscVrPpTbclUnicastNoMatches
mscVrPpTbclUnicastNoMatches.description: This attribute is indicative of the number frames discarded because the MAC address found in the destination field did not match the local MAC address of the bridge port. This counter is only applicable for the protocols that are being routed currently.This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpTbclStaticEntryDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbclStaticEntryDiscards
mscVrPpTbclStaticEntryDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because of the following two reasons: a) there was no entry for the 'allowed to go' field in the static table entry, where the input port is this bridge port. b) for spanning tree bpdus that are locally processed. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. It might prove useful to check the static table entry corresponding to the bridge port in question, if this counter consistently displays a high value. Ideally this counter should be as low as possible.

mscVrPpTbclDynamicEntryDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbclDynamicEntryDiscards
mscVrPpTbclDynamicEntryDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that a) were discarded because of the fact that the bridge port, the frame is to go out of matches the bridge port it came in from or b) if the stp port state of the out port is not forwarding. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpTbclLearningDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbclLearningDiscards
mscVrPpTbclLearningDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded while this bridge port was in a state other than the forwarding state. While in learning state the frame is discarded after the information from its header is learnt. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpTbclInDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbclInDiscards
mscVrPpTbclInDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were received by this bridge port and were discarded by the forwarding process. This includes frames that could have been discarded due to filtering. A repidly increasing value for this attribute could indicate a shrtage of resource in terms of memory needed to process the incoming frames. More memory can be provisioned through the VirtualRouter's memory manager.

mscVrPpTbclInFrames.name: mscVrPpTbclInFrames
mscVrPpTbclInFrames.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that have been received by this port from its segment. Note that a frame received on this bridge port is counted if and only if it can be processed by the bridge logic contained in this bridge unit, a protocol that can be processed by the bridge logic. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpTbclOutFrames.name: mscVrPpTbclOutFrames
mscVrPpTbclOutFrames.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that have been transmitted out this bridge port. Note that frame transmitted out this bridge port is counted if and only if it is for a protocol being processed by the bridge unit. This also includes management frames.This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpTbclStpOperTable.name: mscVrPpTbclStpOperTable
mscVrPpTbclStpOperTable.description: This group houses all the port specific operational attributes that belong to the Stp group. The Stp group is applicable to all the bridge ports that participate in the spanning tree protocol. These attributes reflect the state of the bridge port's participation in the spanning tree protocol.

mscVrPpTbclStpPortState.name: mscVrPpTbclStpPortState
mscVrPpTbclStpPortState.description: This attribute specifies the spanning tree protocol state of the bridge port.

mscVrPpTbclStpTypeOper.name: mscVrPpTbclStpTypeOper
mscVrPpTbclStpTypeOper.description: This attribute specifies the type of spanning tree protocol the port is participating in. A bridge port could participate in either the ieee8021 spanning tree protocol or the dec spanning tree protocol.

mscVrPpTbclDesignatedCost.name: mscVrPpTbclDesignatedCost
mscVrPpTbclDesignatedCost.description: This attribute specifies the path cost of the designated port of the lan segment connected to the port.

mscVrPpTbclPathCostOper.name: mscVrPpTbclPathCostOper
mscVrPpTbclPathCostOper.description: This attribute specifies the contribution of this port, to all the paths to the root bridge that include this port. This attribute pathCostOper will track the value of the attribute pathCostProv when the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is set of off.

mscVrPpTbclDesignatedBridge.name: mscVrPpTbclDesignatedBridge
mscVrPpTbclDesignatedBridge.description: This attribute specifies the identifier of the bridge that this port considers to be the designated bridge.

mscVrPpTbclDesignatedPort.name: mscVrPpTbclDesignatedPort
mscVrPpTbclDesignatedPort.description: This attribute specifies the port identifier of the port on the designated bridge, attached to the same lan as this port is attached to.

mscVrPpTbclForwardTransitions.name: mscVrPpTbclForwardTransitions
mscVrPpTbclForwardTransitions.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of times this bridge port transitioned from the learning state to the forwarding state. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. A rapidly increasing value might be indicative of an unstable spanning tree topology.

mscVrPpTbclBlockingDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbclBlockingDiscards
mscVrPpTbclBlockingDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that were discarded because the bridge port was in the blocking state. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpTbclDesignatedRoot.name: mscVrPpTbclDesignatedRoot
mscVrPpTbclDesignatedRoot.description: This attribute specifies the bridge identifier of the bridge recorded as the root bridge, in the configuration BPDUs sent out by the designated bridge on the segment to which the port is attached.

mscVrPpTbclStatsTable.name: mscVrPpTbclStatsTable
mscVrPpTbclStatsTable.description: This group houses all the statistical attributes applicable to all types of bridge ports and represents the common factor between them. These attributes in part reflect the state of the bridge port.

mscVrPpTbclBadAbstractDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbclBadAbstractDiscards
mscVrPpTbclBadAbstractDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because the data that was abstracted, from frames coming in through this bridge port, did not conform to the format expected by the bridge logic.This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpTbclTinygramFramesIn.name: mscVrPpTbclTinygramFramesIn
mscVrPpTbclTinygramFramesIn.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames received on this bridge port that used the tinygram compression scheme.

mscVrPpTbclTinygramFramesOut.name: mscVrPpTbclTinygramFramesOut
mscVrPpTbclTinygramFramesOut.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames transmitted out this bridge port that used the tinygram compression scheme.

mscVrPpTbclInFilterDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbclInFilterDiscards
mscVrPpTbclInFilterDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded at the in filter point. This includes a) frames discarded due to application of the filter defined with PCF for the in filter point and b) the frames discarded due to domain based filtering at the in filter point. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpTbclOutFilterDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbclOutFilterDiscards
mscVrPpTbclOutFilterDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded at the out filter point. This includes: a) frames discarded due to application of the filter defined with PCF for the out filter point and b) the frames discarded due to domain based filtering at the out filter point. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpTbclNsRowStatusTable.name: mscVrPpTbclNsRowStatusTable
mscVrPpTbclNsRowStatusTable.description: This entry controls the addition and deletion of mscVrPpTbclNs components.

mscVrPpTbclNsRowStatusEntry.name: mscVrPpTbclNsRowStatusEntry
mscVrPpTbclNsRowStatusEntry.description: A single entry in the table represents a single mscVrPpTbclNs component.

mscVrPpTbclNsRowStatus.name: mscVrPpTbclNsRowStatus
mscVrPpTbclNsRowStatus.description: This variable is used as the basis for SNMP naming of mscVrPpTbclNs components. These components can be added and deleted.

mscVrPpTbclNsComponentName.name: mscVrPpTbclNsComponentName
mscVrPpTbclNsComponentName.description: This variable provides the component's string name for use with the ASCII Console Interface

mscVrPpTbclNsStorageType.name: mscVrPpTbclNsStorageType
mscVrPpTbclNsStorageType.description: This variable represents the storage type value for the mscVrPpTbclNs tables.

mscVrPpTbclNsIndex.name: mscVrPpTbclNsIndex
mscVrPpTbclNsIndex.description: This variable represents the index for the mscVrPpTbclNs tables.

mscVrPpTbclNsProvTable.name: mscVrPpTbclNsProvTable
mscVrPpTbclNsProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes associated with Ns. These attributes influence the application of filters to incoming and outgoing frames.

mscVrPpTbclNsIncomingFilter.name: mscVrPpTbclNsIncomingFilter
mscVrPpTbclNsIncomingFilter.description: This attribute specifies the name of the filter to be applied at the incoming filter point.

mscVrPpTbclNsOutgoingFilter.name: mscVrPpTbclNsOutgoingFilter
mscVrPpTbclNsOutgoingFilter.description: This attribute specifies the name of the filter to be applied at the out going filter point.

mscVrPpFddiETBRowStatusTable.name: mscVrPpFddiETBRowStatusTable
mscVrPpFddiETBRowStatusTable.description: This entry controls the addition and deletion of mscVrPpFddiETB components.

mscVrPpFddiETBRowStatusEntry.name: mscVrPpFddiETBRowStatusEntry
mscVrPpFddiETBRowStatusEntry.description: A single entry in the table represents a single mscVrPpFddiETB component.

mscVrPpFddiETBRowStatus.name: mscVrPpFddiETBRowStatus
mscVrPpFddiETBRowStatus.description: This variable is used as the basis for SNMP naming of mscVrPpFddiETB components. These components can be added and deleted.

mscVrPpFddiETBComponentName.name: mscVrPpFddiETBComponentName
mscVrPpFddiETBComponentName.description: This variable provides the component's string name for use with the ASCII Console Interface

mscVrPpFddiETBStorageType.name: mscVrPpFddiETBStorageType
mscVrPpFddiETBStorageType.description: This variable represents the storage type value for the mscVrPpFddiETB tables.

mscVrPpFddiETBIndex.name: mscVrPpFddiETBIndex
mscVrPpFddiETBIndex.description: This variable represents the index for the mscVrPpFddiETB tables.

mscVrPpFddiETBProvTable.name: mscVrPpFddiETBProvTable
mscVrPpFddiETBProvTable.description: This group houses all the provisionable attributes that belong to the this group. This group of attributes is applicable to all types of bridge ports and represent the common factor between them. These attributes influence the working of a bridge port.

mscVrPpFddiETBTranslateIpx.name: mscVrPpFddiETBTranslateIpx
mscVrPpFddiETBTranslateIpx.description: This attribute specifies the type of translation to be performed on frames carrying IPX packets. Ethernet frames carrying IPX payload could be translated to IEEE 802.3 frames (with the same IPX payload) or vice- versa. The main reason to do so is to allow the bridge unit to consistently forward one type of frames carrying IPX packets. Translations can be turned off altogether in which case the IPX frames will pass through the bridge unit unchanged.

mscVrPpFddiETBFragmentIp.name: mscVrPpFddiETBFragmentIp
mscVrPpFddiETBFragmentIp.description: This attribute specifies if or not outbound frames carrying IP datagrams should be fragmented to conform to message transfer unit (mtu) sizes dictated by the media.

mscVrPpFddiETBServiceClass.name: mscVrPpFddiETBServiceClass
mscVrPpFddiETBServiceClass.description: This attribute specifies if the frames should be ordered or not before they are transmitted through a bridge port. If this attribute has a value of ordered the received frames are ordered as in the original message, before they are transmitted out through a bridge port. If it has a value of notOrdered, received then frames pass through the bridge unit in the order they are received. This feature can be used over multiple telecommunication links to increase data flow. Please note that this attribute only affects link protocols and is ineffective with lan media.

mscVrPpFddiETBConvertArpMacAddress.name: mscVrPpFddiETBConvertArpMacAddress
mscVrPpFddiETBConvertArpMacAddress.description: This attribute is indicative of the state of the MAC address format conversion process for ARP/RARP frames. The MAC addresses may be translated if need be from a canonical format to a non-canonical format, based on the needs of the associated media. If this attribute is set to a value of on then all Mac addresses will converted if need be to suit the format of mac address, the outgoing media will support. If this attribute is set to a value of off no such conversion takes place.

mscVrPpFddiETBPortNum.name: mscVrPpFddiETBPortNum
mscVrPpFddiETBPortNum.description: This attribute is indicative of the unique number assigned to the bridge port. It is used for SNMP management of this bridge port and in spanning tree as an identifier this bridge port. Notes regarding portNum: Escape routines exist for initializing, copying, and deleting port numbers. This is necessary because SNMP requires a unique port instance identifier. The initPortNum escape routine sets the port number to a value in the range 1-255 for this purpose. The setCopiedPortNum escape routine exists to maintain the uniqueness of the port number in cases when one port is copied to another. When a bridge port is deleted, the releasePortNum escape routine places the port number being released into a pending deletion state. This is because the port number cannot be re-allocated until the port is truely deleted in the current view. This is necessary since there is no guarantee of order when processing changes to multiple protocol ports so without the pending deletion state, the same port number could be temporarily assigned to two ports for a short period of time. The portNum is set as component critical since bridging also uses the port number as a key for indexing into its data structures. If a port is deleted then re-added under the same protocol port, CAS treats the change as a SET to the portNum attribute.

mscVrPpFddiETBTbProvTable.name: mscVrPpFddiETBTbProvTable
mscVrPpFddiETBTbProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes that belong to the Tb group. The Tb group is only applicable bridge port types that operate in the TB mode. These attributes in part influence the working of a bridge port operating in the TB mode.

mscVrPpFddiETBSecureOption.name: mscVrPpFddiETBSecureOption
mscVrPpFddiETBSecureOption.description: This attribute specifies whether the port secure feature is enabled. The secure feature, if enabled causes the following things to happen: a) disallows dynamic learning, b) disallows frames to be forwarded that do not satisfy the following condition: the mac address of the source should be found in the forwarding table and the destination mac address of the frame should also be found in the forwarding table. In addition to this, the port the frame was received on should figure as the in port, given the destination mac address found in the frame. c) disallows frames to be forwarded if the allowed to go port map for the destination mac address is empty. This feature in effect allows the user to choose the hosts that can generate traffic and the hosts that can receive traffic through this bridge unit.

mscVrPpFddiETBStpProvTable.name: mscVrPpFddiETBStpProvTable
mscVrPpFddiETBStpProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes that belong to the Stp group. The Stp group is applicable to all the bridge ports that participate in the spanning tree protocol. These attributes influence the participation of the bridge port in the spanning tree protocol.

mscVrPpFddiETBAdminStatus.name: mscVrPpFddiETBAdminStatus
mscVrPpFddiETBAdminStatus.description: This attribute defines the current administrative state for this component. enabled indicates that the component is available for operation. disabled indicates the component is unavailable for operation.

mscVrPpFddiETBPortStateStpControl.name: mscVrPpFddiETBPortStateStpControl
mscVrPpFddiETBPortStateStpControl.description: This attribute specifies whether or not spanning tree protocol state for this bridge port is controlled by the spanning tree protocol. In essence it indicates the participation of this bridge port in the spanning tree protocol, by accepting and acting on received bridge protocol data units and by sending out the same. on signifies that this bridge port's spanning tree port state is controlled by the spanning tree protocol. A value of off signifies that the spanning tree port state of this bridge port is unaffected by the spanning tree protocol. This in effect puts the bridge port out of reach of the spanning tree protocol and in the forwarding state. Care should be taken while assigning a value of off to this attribute, as this might cause network loops. Please do not set this attribute to off unless you are absolutely sure about the effect of such an action on your network topology.

mscVrPpFddiETBStpTypeProv.name: mscVrPpFddiETBStpTypeProv
mscVrPpFddiETBStpTypeProv.description: This attribute specifies the type of spanning tree protocol the port is participating in. A bridge port could participate in either the ieee8021 spanning tree protocol or the dec spanning tree protocol. If the value of the attribute protocolSpec in the SpanningTreeProtocol component, provisioned under the TransparentBridge component is in conflict with the value of this attribute, the value of the protocolSpec attribute will prevail. Prevailing stp type is reflected in the value of the attribute stpTypeOper.

mscVrPpFddiETBPortPriority.name: mscVrPpFddiETBPortPriority
mscVrPpFddiETBPortPriority.description: This attribute specifies the value for port priority, which is contained in the first octet of the port identifier. Valid values are as follows: 1) 0..255 for stp type DEC and 2) 0..65535 for stp type IEEE.

mscVrPpFddiETBPathCost.name: mscVrPpFddiETBPathCost
mscVrPpFddiETBPathCost.description: This attribute specifies the contribution of this port, to all the paths to the root bridge that include this port. Please note that the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is applied only when the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is set to on and is ignored if otherwise.

mscVrPpFddiETBPathCostMethod.name: mscVrPpFddiETBPathCostMethod
mscVrPpFddiETBPathCostMethod.description: This attribute specifies the method used by the bridging logic, to calculate the path cost to the bridge considered to be the root bridge in the spanning tree topology. This attribute should be set to off before attempting to provision a value for pathCostProv.

mscVrPpFddiETBDIProvTable.name: mscVrPpFddiETBDIProvTable
mscVrPpFddiETBDIProvTable.description: This group houses all the provisionable, domain specific attributes for a non-encapsulating bridge port.

mscVrPpFddiETBDomainNum.name: mscVrPpFddiETBDomainNum
mscVrPpFddiETBDomainNum.description: This attribute specifies the domain number associated with this bridge port. Domain numbers are used for confining frames to a domain. Domain based filtering provides a complete segregation of traffic based on domain number associated with frames. There can exist only sixteen domains when a spanning tree is desired specific to each domain. When there is only a single spanning tree spanning all the domains the maximum number of domains possible are 4294967293. This attribute is of no relevance when associated with backbone bridge port. Its value is ignored in such a situation.

mscVrPpFddiETBPreserveDomain.name: mscVrPpFddiETBPreserveDomain
mscVrPpFddiETBPreserveDomain.description: This attribute specifies if the domain information should be preserved or embedded in the frame header. This attribute applies only to backbone ports and does not affect the access bridge ports. By setting this attribute to a value of on, domain information could be preserved in frames being tunnelled across the a backbone, so that this information can be deciphered at the other end of the backbone tunnel. This preserves the integrity of the domains thus preventing domain breaches while tunnelling frames across backbone network. If the value of this attribute is set to off then domain information is not preserved in the header of the frames tunnelling through the backbone. This eliminates the overhead incurred to preserve domain information across the backbone while tunnelling frames across it. Preserve domain is relevant when used in conjunction with the following media: FDDI, ATM MPE, Frame Relay and PPP. It is ignored when used with other types of media.

mscVrPpFddiETBStateTable.name: mscVrPpFddiETBStateTable
mscVrPpFddiETBStateTable.description: This group contains the three OSI State attributes. The descriptions generically indicate what each state attribute implies about the component. Note that not all the values and state combinations described here are supported by every component which uses this group. For component-specific information and the valid state combinations, refer to NTP 241-7001-150, Passport Operations and Maintenance Guide.

mscVrPpFddiETBAdminState.name: mscVrPpFddiETBAdminState
mscVrPpFddiETBAdminState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Administrative State of the component. The value locked indicates that the component is administratively prohibited from providing services for its users. A Lock or Lock - force command has been previously issued for this component. When the value is locked, the value of usageState must be idle. The value shuttingDown indicates that the component is administratively permitted to provide service to its existing users only. A Lock command was issued against the component and it is in the process of shutting down. The value unlocked indicates that the component is administratively permitted to provide services for its users. To enter this state, issue an Unlock command to this component.

mscVrPpFddiETBOperationalState.name: mscVrPpFddiETBOperationalState
mscVrPpFddiETBOperationalState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Operational State of the component. The value enabled indicates that the component is available for operation. Note that if adminState is locked, it would still not be providing service. The value disabled indicates that the component is not available for operation. For example, something is wrong with the component itself, or with another component on which this one depends. If the value is disabled, the usageState must be idle.

mscVrPpFddiETBUsageState.name: mscVrPpFddiETBUsageState
mscVrPpFddiETBUsageState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Usage State of the component. The value idle indicates that the component is not currently in use. The value active indicates that the component is in use and has spare capacity to provide for additional users. The value busy indicates that the component is in use and has no spare operating capacity for additional users at this time.

mscVrPpFddiETBOperStatusTable.name: mscVrPpFddiETBOperStatusTable
mscVrPpFddiETBOperStatusTable.description: This group includes the Operational Status attribute. This attribute defines the current operational state of this component.

mscVrPpFddiETBSnmpOperStatus.name: mscVrPpFddiETBSnmpOperStatus
mscVrPpFddiETBSnmpOperStatus.description: The current state of the interface. The up state indicates the interface is operational and capable of forwarding packets. The down state indicates the interface is not operational, thus unable to forward packets. testing state indicates that no operational packets can be passed.

mscVrPpFddiETBOperTable.name: mscVrPpFddiETBOperTable
mscVrPpFddiETBOperTable.description: This group houses all the operational attributes belonging to the base group. The base group of attributes is applicable to all types of bridge ports and represent the common factor between them. These attributes in part, reflect the state of a bridge port.

mscVrPpFddiETBPortName.name: mscVrPpFddiETBPortName
mscVrPpFddiETBPortName.description: The attribute portName is a string of the form 'BridgePortName-i', where BridgePortName is the abbreviation of the corresponding bridge port and i is the instance identifier of the ProtocolPort, the bridge port is provisioned under. For example a TransparentBridgePort provisioned under ProtocolPort/myport would have a name TBP-myport.

mscVrPpFddiETBUpTime.name: mscVrPpFddiETBUpTime
mscVrPpFddiETBUpTime.description: This attribute specifies the accumulated up time of this bridge port since the last reset occurred.

mscVrPpFddiETBDownTime.name: mscVrPpFddiETBDownTime
mscVrPpFddiETBDownTime.description: This attribute specifies the accumulated down time of this bridge port since the last reset occurred.

mscVrPpFddiETBBridgingMode.name: mscVrPpFddiETBBridgingMode
mscVrPpFddiETBBridgingMode.description: This attribute specifies the mode of bridging this port can support. It in turn implies the format of frames, this bridge port can process and forward.

mscVrPpFddiETBBridgePortConfig.name: mscVrPpFddiETBBridgePortConfig
mscVrPpFddiETBBridgePortConfig.description: This attribute specifies the bridge port's configuration. It indicates if the bridge port is operating as an access port or as a backbone port. An access bridge port does not encapsulate a MAC frame and does not preserve domain information in the encapsulation, whereas a backbone bridge port encapsulates the MAC frame and optionally preserves domain information in the encapsulated frame.A backbone bridge port is typically used to transport frames across a high bandwidth backbone network to another bridge unit for further processing/forwarding of the frame.

mscVrPpFddiETBBridgePortType.name: mscVrPpFddiETBBridgePortType
mscVrPpFddiETBBridgePortType.description: This attribute specifies the type of bridge port that was provisioned. It takes into consideration the bridgingMode, bridgePortConfig and the media the bridge port is linked to before branding a bridge port.

mscVrPpFddiETBIfIndex.name: mscVrPpFddiETBIfIndex
mscVrPpFddiETBIfIndex.description: This attribute specifies the index into the Interface Table where in information about the media interface corresponding to the bridge port is maintained.

mscVrPpFddiETBDelayExceededDiscards.name: mscVrPpFddiETBDelayExceededDiscards
mscVrPpFddiETBDelayExceededDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because the time taken to process these frames exceeded the transit delay allowed for this bridge unit. This attribute is not supported by bridging and will always have a value of 0.

mscVrPpFddiETBMtuExceededDiscards.name: mscVrPpFddiETBMtuExceededDiscards
mscVrPpFddiETBMtuExceededDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded because the size of the out bound frame exceeded the message transfer unit (mtu) allowed for the bridge port. Note that this counter only refers to the outbound frames for this bridge port. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. This counter is influenced by the attribute fragmentIp. This counter is incremented when the a frame larger than the mtu allowed is encountered and cannot be fragmented. If this counter is increasing steadily, it might be useful to set the value of the attribute fragmentIp to a value of on.

mscVrPpFddiETBTbOperTable.name: mscVrPpFddiETBTbOperTable
mscVrPpFddiETBTbOperTable.description: This group houses all the port specific operational attributes that belong to the Tb group. This group also houses all the port specific statistical attributes that belong to the Tb group. The Tb group is only applicable bridge port types that operate in the TB mode. These attributes reflect the state of a bridge port operating in the TB mode

mscVrPpFddiETBMaxInfo.name: mscVrPpFddiETBMaxInfo
mscVrPpFddiETBMaxInfo.description: This attribute specifies the maximum size of the information field in a TB frame. This excludes the header field.

mscVrPpFddiETBBadVerifyDiscards.name: mscVrPpFddiETBBadVerifyDiscards
mscVrPpFddiETBBadVerifyDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that were discarded because: a) the value of the secureOption attribute was set to on and b) it is not allowed to receive frames originating from the mac address found in the source address field of the frame (source mac address look up in the forwarding table failed.) on this bridge port. c) for the destination mac address found in the frame, the port the frame was received on does not appear as in port in the corresponding static table entry. Permission to receive frames from a mac address is granted via the static table entries. This attribute, badVerifyDiscards, is directly influenced by: 1. secureOption and 2. the static table entries. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpFddiETBUnicastNoMatches.name: mscVrPpFddiETBUnicastNoMatches
mscVrPpFddiETBUnicastNoMatches.description: This attribute is indicative of the number frames discarded because the MAC address found in the destination field did not match the local MAC address of the bridge port. This counter is only applicable for the protocols that are being routed currently.This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpFddiETBStaticEntryDiscards.name: mscVrPpFddiETBStaticEntryDiscards
mscVrPpFddiETBStaticEntryDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because of the following two reasons: a) there was no entry for the 'allowed to go' field in the static table entry, where the input port is this bridge port. b) for spanning tree bpdus that are locally processed. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. It might prove useful to check the static table entry corresponding to the bridge port in question, if this counter consistently displays a high value. Ideally this counter should be as low as possible.

mscVrPpFddiETBDynamicEntryDiscards.name: mscVrPpFddiETBDynamicEntryDiscards
mscVrPpFddiETBDynamicEntryDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that a) were discarded because of the fact that the bridge port, the frame is to go out of matches the bridge port it came in from or b) if the stp port state of the out port is not forwarding. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpFddiETBLearningDiscards.name: mscVrPpFddiETBLearningDiscards
mscVrPpFddiETBLearningDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded while this bridge port was in a state other than the forwarding state. While in learning state the frame is discarded after the information from its header is learnt. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpFddiETBInDiscards.name: mscVrPpFddiETBInDiscards
mscVrPpFddiETBInDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were received by this bridge port and were discarded by the forwarding process. This includes frames that could have been discarded due to filtering. A repidly increasing value for this attribute could indicate a shrtage of resource in terms of memory needed to process the incoming frames. More memory can be provisioned through the VirtualRouter's memory manager.

mscVrPpFddiETBInFrames.name: mscVrPpFddiETBInFrames
mscVrPpFddiETBInFrames.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that have been received by this port from its segment. Note that a frame received on this bridge port is counted if and only if it can be processed by the bridge logic contained in this bridge unit, a protocol that can be processed by the bridge logic. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpFddiETBOutFrames.name: mscVrPpFddiETBOutFrames
mscVrPpFddiETBOutFrames.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that have been transmitted out this bridge port. Note that frame transmitted out this bridge port is counted if and only if it is for a protocol being processed by the bridge unit. This also includes management frames.This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpFddiETBStpOperTable.name: mscVrPpFddiETBStpOperTable
mscVrPpFddiETBStpOperTable.description: This group houses all the port specific operational attributes that belong to the Stp group. The Stp group is applicable to all the bridge ports that participate in the spanning tree protocol. These attributes reflect the state of the bridge port's participation in the spanning tree protocol.

mscVrPpFddiETBStpPortState.name: mscVrPpFddiETBStpPortState
mscVrPpFddiETBStpPortState.description: This attribute specifies the spanning tree protocol state of the bridge port.

mscVrPpFddiETBStpTypeOper.name: mscVrPpFddiETBStpTypeOper
mscVrPpFddiETBStpTypeOper.description: This attribute specifies the type of spanning tree protocol the port is participating in. A bridge port could participate in either the ieee8021 spanning tree protocol or the dec spanning tree protocol.

mscVrPpFddiETBDesignatedCost.name: mscVrPpFddiETBDesignatedCost
mscVrPpFddiETBDesignatedCost.description: This attribute specifies the path cost of the designated port of the lan segment connected to the port.

mscVrPpFddiETBPathCostOper.name: mscVrPpFddiETBPathCostOper
mscVrPpFddiETBPathCostOper.description: This attribute specifies the contribution of this port, to all the paths to the root bridge that include this port. This attribute pathCostOper will track the value of the attribute pathCostProv when the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is set of off.

mscVrPpFddiETBDesignatedBridge.name: mscVrPpFddiETBDesignatedBridge
mscVrPpFddiETBDesignatedBridge.description: This attribute specifies the identifier of the bridge that this port considers to be the designated bridge.

mscVrPpFddiETBDesignatedPort.name: mscVrPpFddiETBDesignatedPort
mscVrPpFddiETBDesignatedPort.description: This attribute specifies the port identifier of the port on the designated bridge, attached to the same lan as this port is attached to.

mscVrPpFddiETBForwardTransitions.name: mscVrPpFddiETBForwardTransitions
mscVrPpFddiETBForwardTransitions.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of times this bridge port transitioned from the learning state to the forwarding state. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. A rapidly increasing value might be indicative of an unstable spanning tree topology.

mscVrPpFddiETBBlockingDiscards.name: mscVrPpFddiETBBlockingDiscards
mscVrPpFddiETBBlockingDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that were discarded because the bridge port was in the blocking state. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpFddiETBDesignatedRoot.name: mscVrPpFddiETBDesignatedRoot
mscVrPpFddiETBDesignatedRoot.description: This attribute specifies the bridge identifier of the bridge recorded as the root bridge, in the configuration BPDUs sent out by the designated bridge on the segment to which the port is attached.

mscVrPpFddiETBStatsTable.name: mscVrPpFddiETBStatsTable
mscVrPpFddiETBStatsTable.description: This group houses all the statistical attributes applicable to all types of bridge ports and represents the common factor between them. These attributes in part reflect the state of the bridge port.

mscVrPpFddiETBBadAbstractDiscards.name: mscVrPpFddiETBBadAbstractDiscards
mscVrPpFddiETBBadAbstractDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because the data that was abstracted, from frames coming in through this bridge port, did not conform to the format expected by the bridge logic.This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpFddiETBTinygramFramesIn.name: mscVrPpFddiETBTinygramFramesIn
mscVrPpFddiETBTinygramFramesIn.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames received on this bridge port that used the tinygram compression scheme.

mscVrPpFddiETBTinygramFramesOut.name: mscVrPpFddiETBTinygramFramesOut
mscVrPpFddiETBTinygramFramesOut.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames transmitted out this bridge port that used the tinygram compression scheme.

mscVrPpFddiETBInFilterDiscards.name: mscVrPpFddiETBInFilterDiscards
mscVrPpFddiETBInFilterDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded at the in filter point. This includes a) frames discarded due to application of the filter defined with PCF for the in filter point and b) the frames discarded due to domain based filtering at the in filter point. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpFddiETBOutFilterDiscards.name: mscVrPpFddiETBOutFilterDiscards
mscVrPpFddiETBOutFilterDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded at the out filter point. This includes: a) frames discarded due to application of the filter defined with PCF for the out filter point and b) the frames discarded due to domain based filtering at the out filter point. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpFddiETBNsRowStatusTable.name: mscVrPpFddiETBNsRowStatusTable
mscVrPpFddiETBNsRowStatusTable.description: This entry controls the addition and deletion of mscVrPpFddiETBNs components.

mscVrPpFddiETBNsRowStatusEntry.name: mscVrPpFddiETBNsRowStatusEntry
mscVrPpFddiETBNsRowStatusEntry.description: A single entry in the table represents a single mscVrPpFddiETBNs component.

mscVrPpFddiETBNsRowStatus.name: mscVrPpFddiETBNsRowStatus
mscVrPpFddiETBNsRowStatus.description: This variable is used as the basis for SNMP naming of mscVrPpFddiETBNs components. These components can be added and deleted.

mscVrPpFddiETBNsComponentName.name: mscVrPpFddiETBNsComponentName
mscVrPpFddiETBNsComponentName.description: This variable provides the component's string name for use with the ASCII Console Interface

mscVrPpFddiETBNsStorageType.name: mscVrPpFddiETBNsStorageType
mscVrPpFddiETBNsStorageType.description: This variable represents the storage type value for the mscVrPpFddiETBNs tables.

mscVrPpFddiETBNsIndex.name: mscVrPpFddiETBNsIndex
mscVrPpFddiETBNsIndex.description: This variable represents the index for the mscVrPpFddiETBNs tables.

mscVrPpFddiETBNsProvTable.name: mscVrPpFddiETBNsProvTable
mscVrPpFddiETBNsProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes associated with Ns. These attributes influence the application of filters to incoming and outgoing frames.

mscVrPpFddiETBNsIncomingFilter.name: mscVrPpFddiETBNsIncomingFilter
mscVrPpFddiETBNsIncomingFilter.description: This attribute specifies the name of the filter to be applied at the incoming filter point.

mscVrPpFddiETBNsOutgoingFilter.name: mscVrPpFddiETBNsOutgoingFilter
mscVrPpFddiETBNsOutgoingFilter.description: This attribute specifies the name of the filter to be applied at the out going filter point.

mscVrPpTbpRowStatusTable.name: mscVrPpTbpRowStatusTable
mscVrPpTbpRowStatusTable.description: This entry controls the addition and deletion of mscVrPpTbp components.

mscVrPpTbpRowStatusEntry.name: mscVrPpTbpRowStatusEntry
mscVrPpTbpRowStatusEntry.description: A single entry in the table represents a single mscVrPpTbp component.

mscVrPpTbpRowStatus.name: mscVrPpTbpRowStatus
mscVrPpTbpRowStatus.description: This variable is used as the basis for SNMP naming of mscVrPpTbp components. These components can be added and deleted.

mscVrPpTbpComponentName.name: mscVrPpTbpComponentName
mscVrPpTbpComponentName.description: This variable provides the component's string name for use with the ASCII Console Interface

mscVrPpTbpStorageType.name: mscVrPpTbpStorageType
mscVrPpTbpStorageType.description: This variable represents the storage type value for the mscVrPpTbp tables.

mscVrPpTbpIndex.name: mscVrPpTbpIndex
mscVrPpTbpIndex.description: This variable represents the index for the mscVrPpTbp tables.

mscVrPpTbpProvTable.name: mscVrPpTbpProvTable
mscVrPpTbpProvTable.description: This group houses all the provisionable attributes that belong to the this group. This group of attributes is applicable to all types of bridge ports and represent the common factor between them. These attributes influence the working of a bridge port.

mscVrPpTbpTranslateIpx.name: mscVrPpTbpTranslateIpx
mscVrPpTbpTranslateIpx.description: This attribute specifies the type of translation to be performed on frames carrying IPX packets. Ethernet frames carrying IPX payload could be translated to IEEE 802.3 frames (with the same IPX payload) or vice- versa. The main reason to do so is to allow the bridge unit to consistently forward one type of frames carrying IPX packets. Translations can be turned off altogether in which case the IPX frames will pass through the bridge unit unchanged.

mscVrPpTbpFragmentIp.name: mscVrPpTbpFragmentIp
mscVrPpTbpFragmentIp.description: This attribute specifies if or not outbound frames carrying IP datagrams should be fragmented to conform to message transfer unit (mtu) sizes dictated by the media.

mscVrPpTbpServiceClass.name: mscVrPpTbpServiceClass
mscVrPpTbpServiceClass.description: This attribute specifies if the frames should be ordered or not before they are transmitted through a bridge port. If this attribute has a value of ordered the received frames are ordered as in the original message, before they are transmitted out through a bridge port. If it has a value of notOrdered, received then frames pass through the bridge unit in the order they are received. This feature can be used over multiple telecommunication links to increase data flow. Please note that this attribute only affects link protocols and is ineffective with lan media.

mscVrPpTbpConvertArpMacAddress.name: mscVrPpTbpConvertArpMacAddress
mscVrPpTbpConvertArpMacAddress.description: This attribute is indicative of the state of the MAC address format conversion process for ARP/RARP frames. The MAC addresses may be translated if need be from a canonical format to a non-canonical format, based on the needs of the associated media. If this attribute is set to a value of on then all Mac addresses will converted if need be to suit the format of mac address, the outgoing media will support. If this attribute is set to a value of off no such conversion takes place.

mscVrPpTbpPortNum.name: mscVrPpTbpPortNum
mscVrPpTbpPortNum.description: This attribute is indicative of the unique number assigned to the bridge port. It is used for SNMP management of this bridge port and in spanning tree as an identifier this bridge port. Notes regarding portNum: Escape routines exist for initializing, copying, and deleting port numbers. This is necessary because SNMP requires a unique port instance identifier. The initPortNum escape routine sets the port number to a value in the range 1-255 for this purpose. The setCopiedPortNum escape routine exists to maintain the uniqueness of the port number in cases when one port is copied to another. When a bridge port is deleted, the releasePortNum escape routine places the port number being released into a pending deletion state. This is because the port number cannot be re-allocated until the port is truely deleted in the current view. This is necessary since there is no guarantee of order when processing changes to multiple protocol ports so without the pending deletion state, the same port number could be temporarily assigned to two ports for a short period of time. The portNum is set as component critical since bridging also uses the port number as a key for indexing into its data structures. If a port is deleted then re-added under the same protocol port, CAS treats the change as a SET to the portNum attribute.

mscVrPpTbpTbProvTable.name: mscVrPpTbpTbProvTable
mscVrPpTbpTbProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes that belong to the Tb group. The Tb group is only applicable bridge port types that operate in the TB mode. These attributes in part influence the working of a bridge port operating in the TB mode.

mscVrPpTbpSecureOption.name: mscVrPpTbpSecureOption
mscVrPpTbpSecureOption.description: This attribute specifies whether the port secure feature is enabled. The secure feature, if enabled causes the following things to happen: a) disallows dynamic learning, b) disallows frames to be forwarded that do not satisfy the following condition: the mac address of the source should be found in the forwarding table and the destination mac address of the frame should also be found in the forwarding table. In addition to this, the port the frame was received on should figure as the in port, given the destination mac address found in the frame. c) disallows frames to be forwarded if the allowed to go port map for the destination mac address is empty. This feature in effect allows the user to choose the hosts that can generate traffic and the hosts that can receive traffic through this bridge unit.

mscVrPpTbpStpProvTable.name: mscVrPpTbpStpProvTable
mscVrPpTbpStpProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes that belong to the Stp group. The Stp group is applicable to all the bridge ports that participate in the spanning tree protocol. These attributes influence the participation of the bridge port in the spanning tree protocol.

mscVrPpTbpAdminStatus.name: mscVrPpTbpAdminStatus
mscVrPpTbpAdminStatus.description: This attribute defines the current administrative state for this component. enabled indicates that the component is available for operation. disabled indicates the component is unavailable for operation.

mscVrPpTbpPortStateStpControl.name: mscVrPpTbpPortStateStpControl
mscVrPpTbpPortStateStpControl.description: This attribute specifies whether or not spanning tree protocol state for this bridge port is controlled by the spanning tree protocol. In essence it indicates the participation of this bridge port in the spanning tree protocol, by accepting and acting on received bridge protocol data units and by sending out the same. on signifies that this bridge port's spanning tree port state is controlled by the spanning tree protocol. A value of off signifies that the spanning tree port state of this bridge port is unaffected by the spanning tree protocol. This in effect puts the bridge port out of reach of the spanning tree protocol and in the forwarding state. Care should be taken while assigning a value of off to this attribute, as this might cause network loops. Please do not set this attribute to off unless you are absolutely sure about the effect of such an action on your network topology.

mscVrPpTbpStpTypeProv.name: mscVrPpTbpStpTypeProv
mscVrPpTbpStpTypeProv.description: This attribute specifies the type of spanning tree protocol the port is participating in. A bridge port could participate in either the ieee8021 spanning tree protocol or the dec spanning tree protocol. If the value of the attribute protocolSpec in the SpanningTreeProtocol component, provisioned under the TransparentBridge component is in conflict with the value of this attribute, the value of the protocolSpec attribute will prevail. Prevailing stp type is reflected in the value of the attribute stpTypeOper.

mscVrPpTbpPortPriority.name: mscVrPpTbpPortPriority
mscVrPpTbpPortPriority.description: This attribute specifies the value for port priority, which is contained in the first octet of the port identifier. Valid values are as follows: 1) 0..255 for stp type DEC and 2) 0..65535 for stp type IEEE.

mscVrPpTbpPathCost.name: mscVrPpTbpPathCost
mscVrPpTbpPathCost.description: This attribute specifies the contribution of this port, to all the paths to the root bridge that include this port. Please note that the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is applied only when the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is set to on and is ignored if otherwise.

mscVrPpTbpPathCostMethod.name: mscVrPpTbpPathCostMethod
mscVrPpTbpPathCostMethod.description: This attribute specifies the method used by the bridging logic, to calculate the path cost to the bridge considered to be the root bridge in the spanning tree topology. This attribute should be set to off before attempting to provision a value for pathCostProv.

mscVrPpTbpDIProvTable.name: mscVrPpTbpDIProvTable
mscVrPpTbpDIProvTable.description: This group houses all the provisionable, domain specific attributes for a non-encapsulating bridge port.

mscVrPpTbpDomainNum.name: mscVrPpTbpDomainNum
mscVrPpTbpDomainNum.description: This attribute specifies the domain number associated with this bridge port. Domain numbers are used for confining frames to a domain. Domain based filtering provides a complete segregation of traffic based on domain number associated with frames. There can exist only sixteen domains when a spanning tree is desired specific to each domain. When there is only a single spanning tree spanning all the domains the maximum number of domains possible are 4294967293. This attribute is of no relevance when associated with backbone bridge port. Its value is ignored in such a situation.

mscVrPpTbpPreserveDomain.name: mscVrPpTbpPreserveDomain
mscVrPpTbpPreserveDomain.description: This attribute specifies if the domain information should be preserved or embedded in the frame header. This attribute applies only to backbone ports and does not affect the access bridge ports. By setting this attribute to a value of on, domain information could be preserved in frames being tunnelled across the a backbone, so that this information can be deciphered at the other end of the backbone tunnel. This preserves the integrity of the domains thus preventing domain breaches while tunnelling frames across backbone network. If the value of this attribute is set to off then domain information is not preserved in the header of the frames tunnelling through the backbone. This eliminates the overhead incurred to preserve domain information across the backbone while tunnelling frames across it. Preserve domain is relevant when used in conjunction with the following media: FDDI, ATM MPE, Frame Relay and PPP. It is ignored when used with other types of media.

mscVrPpTbpStateTable.name: mscVrPpTbpStateTable
mscVrPpTbpStateTable.description: This group contains the three OSI State attributes. The descriptions generically indicate what each state attribute implies about the component. Note that not all the values and state combinations described here are supported by every component which uses this group. For component-specific information and the valid state combinations, refer to NTP 241-7001-150, Passport Operations and Maintenance Guide.

mscVrPpTbpAdminState.name: mscVrPpTbpAdminState
mscVrPpTbpAdminState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Administrative State of the component. The value locked indicates that the component is administratively prohibited from providing services for its users. A Lock or Lock - force command has been previously issued for this component. When the value is locked, the value of usageState must be idle. The value shuttingDown indicates that the component is administratively permitted to provide service to its existing users only. A Lock command was issued against the component and it is in the process of shutting down. The value unlocked indicates that the component is administratively permitted to provide services for its users. To enter this state, issue an Unlock command to this component.

mscVrPpTbpOperationalState.name: mscVrPpTbpOperationalState
mscVrPpTbpOperationalState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Operational State of the component. The value enabled indicates that the component is available for operation. Note that if adminState is locked, it would still not be providing service. The value disabled indicates that the component is not available for operation. For example, something is wrong with the component itself, or with another component on which this one depends. If the value is disabled, the usageState must be idle.

mscVrPpTbpUsageState.name: mscVrPpTbpUsageState
mscVrPpTbpUsageState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Usage State of the component. The value idle indicates that the component is not currently in use. The value active indicates that the component is in use and has spare capacity to provide for additional users. The value busy indicates that the component is in use and has no spare operating capacity for additional users at this time.

mscVrPpTbpOperStatusTable.name: mscVrPpTbpOperStatusTable
mscVrPpTbpOperStatusTable.description: This group includes the Operational Status attribute. This attribute defines the current operational state of this component.

mscVrPpTbpSnmpOperStatus.name: mscVrPpTbpSnmpOperStatus
mscVrPpTbpSnmpOperStatus.description: The current state of the interface. The up state indicates the interface is operational and capable of forwarding packets. The down state indicates the interface is not operational, thus unable to forward packets. testing state indicates that no operational packets can be passed.

mscVrPpTbpOperTable.name: mscVrPpTbpOperTable
mscVrPpTbpOperTable.description: This group houses all the operational attributes belonging to the base group. The base group of attributes is applicable to all types of bridge ports and represent the common factor between them. These attributes in part, reflect the state of a bridge port.

mscVrPpTbpPortName.name: mscVrPpTbpPortName
mscVrPpTbpPortName.description: The attribute portName is a string of the form 'BridgePortName-i', where BridgePortName is the abbreviation of the corresponding bridge port and i is the instance identifier of the ProtocolPort, the bridge port is provisioned under. For example a TransparentBridgePort provisioned under ProtocolPort/myport would have a name TBP-myport.

mscVrPpTbpUpTime.name: mscVrPpTbpUpTime
mscVrPpTbpUpTime.description: This attribute specifies the accumulated up time of this bridge port since the last reset occurred.

mscVrPpTbpDownTime.name: mscVrPpTbpDownTime
mscVrPpTbpDownTime.description: This attribute specifies the accumulated down time of this bridge port since the last reset occurred.

mscVrPpTbpBridgingMode.name: mscVrPpTbpBridgingMode
mscVrPpTbpBridgingMode.description: This attribute specifies the mode of bridging this port can support. It in turn implies the format of frames, this bridge port can process and forward.

mscVrPpTbpBridgePortConfig.name: mscVrPpTbpBridgePortConfig
mscVrPpTbpBridgePortConfig.description: This attribute specifies the bridge port's configuration. It indicates if the bridge port is operating as an access port or as a backbone port. An access bridge port does not encapsulate a MAC frame and does not preserve domain information in the encapsulation, whereas a backbone bridge port encapsulates the MAC frame and optionally preserves domain information in the encapsulated frame.A backbone bridge port is typically used to transport frames across a high bandwidth backbone network to another bridge unit for further processing/forwarding of the frame.

mscVrPpTbpBridgePortType.name: mscVrPpTbpBridgePortType
mscVrPpTbpBridgePortType.description: This attribute specifies the type of bridge port that was provisioned. It takes into consideration the bridgingMode, bridgePortConfig and the media the bridge port is linked to before branding a bridge port.

mscVrPpTbpIfIndex.name: mscVrPpTbpIfIndex
mscVrPpTbpIfIndex.description: This attribute specifies the index into the Interface Table where in information about the media interface corresponding to the bridge port is maintained.

mscVrPpTbpDelayExceededDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbpDelayExceededDiscards
mscVrPpTbpDelayExceededDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because the time taken to process these frames exceeded the transit delay allowed for this bridge unit. This attribute is not supported by bridging and will always have a value of 0.

mscVrPpTbpMtuExceededDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbpMtuExceededDiscards
mscVrPpTbpMtuExceededDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded because the size of the out bound frame exceeded the message transfer unit (mtu) allowed for the bridge port. Note that this counter only refers to the outbound frames for this bridge port. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. This counter is influenced by the attribute fragmentIp. This counter is incremented when the a frame larger than the mtu allowed is encountered and cannot be fragmented. If this counter is increasing steadily, it might be useful to set the value of the attribute fragmentIp to a value of on.

mscVrPpTbpTbOperTable.name: mscVrPpTbpTbOperTable
mscVrPpTbpTbOperTable.description: This group houses all the port specific operational attributes that belong to the Tb group. This group also houses all the port specific statistical attributes that belong to the Tb group. The Tb group is only applicable bridge port types that operate in the TB mode. These attributes reflect the state of a bridge port operating in the TB mode

mscVrPpTbpMaxInfo.name: mscVrPpTbpMaxInfo
mscVrPpTbpMaxInfo.description: This attribute specifies the maximum size of the information field in a TB frame. This excludes the header field.

mscVrPpTbpBadVerifyDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbpBadVerifyDiscards
mscVrPpTbpBadVerifyDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that were discarded because: a) the value of the secureOption attribute was set to on and b) it is not allowed to receive frames originating from the mac address found in the source address field of the frame (source mac address look up in the forwarding table failed.) on this bridge port. c) for the destination mac address found in the frame, the port the frame was received on does not appear as in port in the corresponding static table entry. Permission to receive frames from a mac address is granted via the static table entries. This attribute, badVerifyDiscards, is directly influenced by: 1. secureOption and 2. the static table entries. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpTbpUnicastNoMatches.name: mscVrPpTbpUnicastNoMatches
mscVrPpTbpUnicastNoMatches.description: This attribute is indicative of the number frames discarded because the MAC address found in the destination field did not match the local MAC address of the bridge port. This counter is only applicable for the protocols that are being routed currently.This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

mscVrPpTbpStaticEntryDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbpStaticEntryDiscards
mscVrPpTbpStaticEntryDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because of the following two reasons: a) there was no entry for the 'allowed to go' field in the static table entry, where the input port is this bridge port. b) for spanning tree bpdus that are locally processed. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. It might prove useful to check the static table entry corresponding to the bridge port in question, if this counter consistently displays a high value. Ideally this counter should be as low as possible.

mscVrPpTbpDynamicEntryDiscards.name: mscVrPpTbpDynamicEntryDiscards
mscVrPpTbpDynamicEntryDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that a) were discarded because of the fact that the bridge port, the frame is to go out of matches the bridge port it came in from or b) if the stp port state of the out port is not forwarding.
